wikipedia_page.main: Sir John Edmond Gough  (25 October 1871 – 22 February 1915), was an early 20th century British Army General, and a recipient of the Victoria Cross, the highest award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to British and Commonwealth forces.

response: * Major-General Sir John Gough (1871–1915), Somaliland Campaign Victoria Cross
* John Gough – Awarded a Victoria Cross for his actions as a column commander during the Third Somaliland Expedition against Hassan.

The expedition ended in failure soon after. The Haroun annihilated a British detachment near Gumburru and then forced another Daratoleh back to base. For trying to save a fellow officer during the fighting withdrawal three officers John Gough, George Rolland, William George Walker were awarded Victoria Crosses."Gumburru and Daratoleh: 1903 Somaliland Campaign" With 1,200–1,500 rifles, 4,000 ponies and some spearmen, he occupied the Nugal Valley from Halin in the British protectorate to Ilig (or Illig) on the Italian-held coast. The main British force near Galad (Galadi) under General William Manning retreated north along the line Bohotleh–Burao–Sheekh. This "old-established line" had already been breached by the Haroun when they invaded the Nugal.Cunliffe-Owen (1905), 169. By the end of June, the withdrawal was complete.

response: The youngest recipient of the VC was Andrew Fitzgibbon who was fifteen at the time of the action that earned him the VC. By comparison, the oldest recipient was William Raynor at 61 at the time of his action in 1857.Ashcroft, Michael; p.17 There have been several VCs awarded to close relatives. Four pairs of brothers and three fathers and sons have been awarded the VC. In his book Victoria Cross Heroes, Lord Ashcroft notes the story of the Gough family as possibly the "bravest family." Major Charles Gough was awarded the VC in 1857 for saving his brother, Lieutenant Hugh Gough who then went on to win a VC himself in the same year, after he charged enemy guns. Charles' son, John Gough, then went on to win the family's third VC in 1903.Ashcroft, Michael; p.18
* Died: John Gough, British army officer, commander of Kitchener's Army, recipient of the Victoria Cross, Order of the Bath, and Order of St Michael and St George (killed by a sniper) (b. 1871)
